feature
Add facebook OPT series cpp model.  [jira-811](https://jira.devtools.intel.com/browse/NLPTOOLKIU-811)
model list:
 - [125m](https://huggingface.co/facebook/opt-125m/blob/main/config.json)
 - [350m](https://huggingface.co/facebook/opt-350m/blob/main/config.json)
 - [1.3b](https://huggingface.co/facebook/opt-1.3b/blob/main/config.json)
 - [2.7b](https://huggingface.co/facebook/opt-2.7b/blob/main/config.json)
 - [6.7b](https://huggingface.co/facebook/opt-6.7b/blob/main/config.json)
 - [13b](https://huggingface.co/facebook/opt-13b/blob/main/config.json)
 - [30b](https://huggingface.co/facebook/opt-30b/blob/main/config.json)
 - [66b](https://huggingface.co/facebook/opt-66b/blob/main/config.json) (optional)

## Description
`n_ctx = 2048`
- [origin paper](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2205.01068.pdf)
- [modeling.py](https://github.com/huggingface/transformers/blob/main/src/transformers/models/opt/modeling_opt.py)
- forward differences:
     - [Learned pos embeddings](https://github.com/huggingface/transformers/blob/main/src/transformers/models/opt/modeling_opt.py#L98)
     - FFN activation = Relu
     - word_dim_project gemm (in and out) in some models
     - do_layer_norm_before

title: Fix dockerfile
body:
## Type of Change

fix or documentation：Correct the way some of the code is written in the Dockerfile.


## Description
Here is a list of activities I had worked upon:1. Checked for misconfigurations in the Dockerfile. - Analyzed the docker files in the shared code, and observed Image might run with root as the default user. Running containers as a privileged user weakens their runtime security, allowing any user whose code runs on the container to perform administrative actions. Oberved this issue in multiple Dockerfiles.- Detected S3 Bucket https://intel-extension-for-pytorch.s3.amazonaws.com/ and checked for common AWS S3 Bucket Misconfigurations. No issues found.- Found that in one of the Dockerfile, it uses wget command to download from the S3 bucket. The usage of HTTPS is not enforced here. As it is possible for the HTTP client to follow redirects, such redirects might lead to websites using HTTP. The recommended secure coding practice here would be to disable redirects and ensure that the HTTP client only accepts HTTPS pages.- Dockerfile uses an unsafe way to install npm packages which can lead to the execution of shell scripts. For example: workflows/chatbot/demo/docker/Dockerfile it runs the command npm install -g n omitting --ignore-scripts which can lead to the execution of shell scripts. When installing dependencies, package managers like npm will automatically execute shell scripts distributed along with the source code.2. Checked for exposure of any sensitive and hardcoded secrets in source repo & git history. Did not find any issues.3. Performed a SonarQube scan on the repository.

The tool reported a total of 294 security issues which were classified as below:
Denial of Service, Medium, 90
Dockerfile Permission Issues, Medium, 13
Weak Cryptography, Medium, 59
Log Injection, Low, 74
Usage of HTTP instead of HTTPS, Low, 10
Others, Low, 48

I analyzed all the reported issues and they were mostly false positives or did not have a way where it could be exploited. There were some valid issues identified in Dockerfiles, which are already mentioned above and some which are highlighted below.
In one of the HTML file in the workflows directory, found few javascript files loaded from external sources without using resource integrity feature. This could lead to the unexpected execution of malicious code in the application.
Found multiple places where the code uses a publicly writable directory like /tmp for saving the intermediary model output. An application manipulating files from these folders is exposed to race conditions on filenames: a malicious user can try to create a file with a predictable name before the application does. A successful attack can result in other files being accessed, modified, corrupted or deleted. The recommended secure coding practice would be to use a dedicated sub-folder with tightly controlled permissions.Next steps:
Perform OWASP Dependency checks
Perform static analysis and analyze results using other tools

detail description 
JIRA ticket: [NLPTOOLKIU-815](https://jira.devtools.intel.com/browse/NLPTOOLKIU-815)

## Expected Behavior & Potential Risk

the expected behavior that triggered by this PR 

## How has this PR been tested?

how to reproduce the test (including hardware information)

## Dependency Change?

any library dependency introduced or removed

title: Create a new package Q_bits for weight_only with JBLAS kernel
body:
## Type of Change

feature
No API changed

## Description

Q_bits is a package for weight_only quantization with JBLAS kernel. It include weight_only ops kenel implementation and weight_only ops class for PyTorch(inherit from torch.nn.Module). It also provide convert tool to convert fp32 model to weight_only quantized model.

## How has this PR been tested?

UT cases have passed.

title: PyTorch command failed on worker #gwnpy
body:
![image](https://github.com/intel/intel-extension-for-transformers/assets/107987033/8462117b-37ee-40b2-aed9-5c669d2c04d0)

Running this script https://github.com/intel/intel-extension-for-transformers/tree/main/workflows/chatbot/fine_tuning
python finetune_clm.py
--model_name_or_path "mosaicml/mpt-7b"
--bf16 True
--train_file "/path/to/alpaca_data.json"
--dataset_concatenation
--per_device_train_batch_size 2
--per_device_eval_batch_size 2
--gradient_accumulation_steps 4
--evaluation_strategy "no"
--save_strategy "steps"
--save_steps 2000
--save_total_limit 1
--learning_rate 1e-4
--logging_steps 1
--do_train
--num_train_epochs 3
--overwrite_output_dir
--log_level info
--output_dir ./mpt_peft_finetuned_model
--peft lora
--trust_remote_code True
--tokenizer_name "EleutherAI/gpt-neox-20b"
--habana
--use_habana
--use_lazy_mode \

in a container image using kubernetes.

title: File "/usr/local/lib/python3.10/dist-packages/torch/distributed/elastic/utils/store.py" ; data = store.get(f"{prefix}{idx}") RuntimeError: Socket Timeout
body:
File "/usr/local/lib/python3.10/dist-packages/torch/distributed/elastic/utils/store.py", line 34, in get_all
data = store.get(f"{prefix}{idx}")
RuntimeError: Socket Timeout
PyTorch command failed on worker #vbsbi
PyTorch command failed on worker #5xzl9
An error has caused the experiment to fail

Running this script https://github.com/intel/intel-extension-for-transformers/tree/main/workflows/chatbot/fine_tuning
python finetune_clm.py \
        --model_name_or_path "mosaicml/mpt-7b" \
        --bf16 True \
        --train_file "/path/to/alpaca_data.json" \
        --dataset_concatenation \
        --per_device_train_batch_size 2 \
        --per_device_eval_batch_size 2 \
        --gradient_accumulation_steps 4 \
        --evaluation_strategy "no" \
        --save_strategy "steps" \
        --save_steps 2000 \
        --save_total_limit 1 \
        --learning_rate 1e-4  \
        --logging_steps 1 \

title: OSError: You seem to have cloned a repository without having git-lfs installed. while running on habana-gaudi
body:
Followed these commands: -
```
git clone https://github.com/intel/intel-extension-for-transformers.git
cd ./intel-extension-for-transformers/
apt-get update
apt-get install git-lfs
git-lfs install
docker run -it --runtime=habana -e HABANA_VISIBLE_DEVICES=all -e OMPI_MCA_btl_vader_single_copy_mechanism=none --cap-add=sys_nice --net=host --ipc=host -v $(pwd):/intel-extension-for-transformers vault.habana.ai/gaudi-docker/1.10.0/ubuntu22.04/habanalabs/pytorch-installer-2.0.1:latest
cd /intel-extension-for-transformers/workflows/chatbot/inference/
git clone https://huggingface.co/mosaicml/mpt-7b-chat
pip install datasets
pip install optimum
pip install git+https://github.com/huggingface/optimum-habana.git
pip install peft
pip install einops
pip install git+https://github.com/HabanaAI/DeepSpeed.git@1.10.0
```
But while running
```
python generate.py --base_model_path "./mpt-7b-chat" \
             --habana \
             --tokenizer_name "EleutherAI/gpt-neox-20b" \
             --use_hpu_graphs \
             --use_kv_cache \
             --instructions "Transform the following sentence into one that shows contrast. The tree is rotten."
```
ran into this error 
```
OSError: You seem to have cloned a repository without having git-lfs installed. Please install git-lfs and run `git lfs install` followed by `git lfs pull` in the folder you cloned.
```
Tried doing git init and re cloning the mpt repo but to no avail.
git lfs install works but git lfs pull doesn't.
When I do git lfs pull, it says
```
Not in a git repository
```

title: Fixd the typo in pruning.md
body:
I installed `intel-extension-for-transformers` for pruning a whisper model. While following the pruning.md in the docs, I tried running the import statements to make sure that the installation is working well. I tried running the code 
`from intel_extension_for_transformers.optimization import metric, objectives, PrunerConfig, PruningConfig`, but I was getting an error 
`ImportError: cannot import name 'metric' from 'intel_extension_for_transformers.optimization' (/home/___/anaconda3/envs/nlp/lib/python3.10/site-packages/intel_extension_for_transformers/optimization/__init__.py)
`
I thought maybe it's some problem installing with pip, and I uninstalled it and starting installing from scratch, but I was again getting the same error. It was only when I went into the source code, I realised that in the code snippet given in the github, metrics is written as `metric` which was caused me some frustration. Creating this pull request so that other's may not face this issue. 

Have a nice day :)

title: What does sparsity ratio mean in this work?
body:
In NVIDIA's version of 2x2 structures sparsity, exactly 2 non-zero values are allowed giving a sparsity ratio of exactly 50%. A few questions about sparsity ratio in this work:
1. Can different 4x1 blocks have different levels of sparsity (i.e. from 25% to 100%)? If so, this is more flexible than NVIDIA's hardware based structured sparsity. Is my understanding correct?
2. Does a sparsity ratio of 80% mean the average sparsity of 4x1 blocks averaged over a layer? Confusion arises because a single 4x1 block can only have a few discrete number of sparsity ratios (0, 25, 50, 75 and 100%)

title: Dependency for ipex not included in the requirements
body:
After following the step by step process, for prerequirsites here
https://github.com/intel/intel-extension-for-transformers/blob/main/examples/huggingface/pytorch/language-modeling/quantization/README.md

And executing the command for Quantization for MPT-7B-chat
```
# "--sq" is used to enable smooth quant
# "--int8_bf16_mixed" is used to enable int8-bf16 mixed mode for platform that natively supports bf16
python run_clm_no_trainer.py \
    --model mosaicml/mpt-7b-chat \
    --revision c8d4750ac8421303665d6ecc253950c69b56d324 \
    --quantize \
    --sq \
    --alpha 0.85 \
    --ipex \
    --output_dir "saved_results"
```

This has a dependency on ipex, but its not included in the parent `requirements.txt` or the  `examples/huggingface/pytorch/language-modeling/quantization/requirements.txt` path

This leads to this error while excuting the above command
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/devcloud/itrex/examples/huggingface/pytorch/language-modeling/quantization/run_clm_no_trainer.py", line 53, in <module>
    import intel_extension_for_pytorch as ipex
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'intel_extension_for_pytorch'
```

title: Exporting Gpt2 model failing for `trainer.export_to_onnx` with `IndexError: Dimension out of range`
body:
Hi intel team,

I have pruned and quantized several models using your toolkit, and I'm currently aiming to do inference using your pipeline to my gpt2 code generation model. To do so I need to export the model to the onnx format. Running `trainer.export_to_onnx` on both the int8 and fp32 model fails to export it, raising `IndexError: Dimension out of range`. Using `torch.onnx.export` alone works just fine, therefore the error must be somewhere in the methods in `trainer.py`. I want to avoid using `torch.onnx.export` because I need the optimized performance for the int8 model, offered by your executor backend.

Quantized model at: https://huggingface.co/dscc/CodeGPT-Py150_q_all_layers_sym_per_tensor/tree/main

### To reproduce:
```
import os
import numpy as np
from datasets import load_dataset, Dataset, load_metric
from transformers import AutoTokenizer, AutoModelForCausalLM, TrainingArguments, DataCollatorForLanguageModeling,EvalPrediction
from intel_extension_for_transformers.optimization.trainer import NLPTrainer

from pandarallel import pandarallel
pandarallel.initialize(progress_bar=True, nb_workers=32)

from tqdm import tqdm
tqdm.pandas()

os.environ["CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES"] = ""
os.environ["WANDB_DISABLED"] = "true"

dataset = load_dataset("0n1xus/codexglue", 'code-completion-token-py150')
model = AutoModelForCausalLM.from_pretrained("dscc/CodeGPT-Py150_q_all_layers_sym_per_tensor")

tokenizer = AutoTokenizer.from_pretrained("microsoft/CodeGPT-small-py", truncation_side='left')

train = dataset['train'].to_pandas()
valid = dataset['validation'].to_pandas()
test = dataset['test'].to_pandas()

# Sample just 10 examples to speed up tokenization
train = train.sample(10)
valid = valid.sample(10)
test = test.sample(10)

# We split the input code snippet and take the last line as the expected output and the rest as input
def split_input_output(x):
    split_seq = x['code'].split('<EOL>')
    return ['<EOL>'.join(split_seq[0:-1]) + '<EOL>', split_seq[-1]]

# Tokenize the sequences
# CodeGPT supports 1024 tokens max so we truncate longer sequences
# We add padding to make sure all sequences the same length
def tokenize_both(batch):
    return tokenizer(batch['input'], batch['output'], padding="max_length", truncation=True, max_length=1024, return_tensors='pt')

# Apply split function to the Dataframes
train[['input', 'output']] = train.progress_apply(split_input_output, axis =1, result_type="expand")
valid[['input', 'output']] = valid.progress_apply(split_input_output, axis =1, result_type="expand")
test[['input', 'output']] = test.progress_apply(split_input_output, axis =1, result_type="expand")

# Tokenize train and valid
train_ds = Dataset.from_pandas(train, split="train")
train_ds = train_ds.map(tokenize_both, num_proc=1)

valid_ds = Dataset.from_pandas(valid, split="validation")
valid_ds = valid_ds.map(tokenize_both, num_proc=1)


training_args = TrainingArguments(
    no_cuda=True,
    do_train=True,
    do_eval=True,

    output_dir="./test_epoch",  #The output directory
    overwrite_output_dir=True,  #overwrite the content of the output directory
    num_train_epochs=2,  # number of training epochs
    per_device_train_batch_size=1,  # batch size for training
    per_device_eval_batch_size=1,  # batch size for evaluation
    eval_steps=200,  # Number of update steps between two evaluations.
    save_steps=800,  # after # steps model is saved
    warmup_steps=500,  # number of warmup steps for learning rate scheduler
    prediction_loss_only=True,
    seed=42
)

data_collator = DataCollatorForLanguageModeling(tokenizer=tokenizer, mlm=False, return_tensors='pt')

task_metric = load_metric("accuracy")

def compute_metrics(p: EvalPrediction):
    preds = p.predictions[0] if isinstance(p.predictions, tuple) else p.predictions
    preds = np.argmax(preds, axis=1)

    result = task_metric.compute(predictions=preds, references=p.label_ids)
    if len(result) > 1:
        result["combined_score"] = np.mean(list(result.values())).item()
    return result

trainer = NLPTrainer(
    model=model,
    args=training_args,
    train_dataset=train_ds,
    eval_dataset=valid_ds,
    data_collator=data_collator,
    tokenizer=tokenizer,
    compute_metrics=compute_metrics
)

trainer.enable_inc_quant = True
trainer.enable_executor = True
trainer.export_to_onnx("test.onnx")
```

### Raising:
```
 File "code_completion.py", line 96, in <module>
    trainer.export_to_onnx("test.onnx")
  File "\venv\lib\site-packages\intel_extension_for_transformers\optimization\trainer.py", line 2006, in export_to_onnx
    self.export_to_int8_onnx(*args, **kwargs)
  File "\venv\lib\site-packages\intel_extension_for_transformers\optimization\trainer.py", line 2179, in export_to_int8_onnx
    self.export_to_fp32_onnx(fp32_path,
  File "\venv\lib\site-packages\intel_extension_for_transformers\optimization\trainer.py", line 2045, in export_to_fp32_onnx
    torch.onnx.export(
  File "\venv\lib\site-packages\torch\onnx\utils.py", line 506, in export
    _export(
  File "\venv\lib\site-packages\torch\onnx\utils.py", line 1548, in _export
    graph, params_dict, torch_out = _model_to_graph(
  File "\venv\lib\site-packages\torch\onnx\utils.py", line 1113, in _model_to_graph
    graph, params, torch_out, module = _create_jit_graph(model, args)
  File "\venv\lib\site-packages\torch\onnx\utils.py", line 989, in _create_jit_graph
    graph, torch_out = _trace_and_get_graph_from_model(model, args)
  File "\venv\lib\site-packages\torch\onnx\utils.py", line 893, in _trace_and_get_graph_from_model
    trace_graph, torch_out, inputs_states = torch.jit._get_trace_graph(
  File "\venv\lib\site-packages\torch\nn\modules\module.py", line 1488, in _slow_forward
    result = self.forward(*input, **kwargs)
  File "\venv\lib\site-packages\transformers\models\gpt2\modeling_gpt2.py", line 1076, in forward
    transformer_outputs = self.transformer(
  File "\venv\lib\site-packages\torch\nn\modules\module.py", line 1501, in _call_impl
    return forward_call(*args, **kwargs)
  File "\venv\lib\site-packages\torch\nn\modules\module.py", line 1488, in _slow_forward
    result = self.forward(*input, **kwargs)
  File "\venv\lib\site-packages\transformers\models\gpt2\modeling_gpt2.py", line 800, in forward
    past_length = past_key_values[0][0].size(-2)
IndexError: Dimension out of range (expected to be in range of [-1, 0], but got -2)
```

### Urgency
medium-high

### Platform
Linux/Windows

### Package versions
python 3.9
torch 2.0.1
transformers 4.29.2
intel-extension-for-transformers 1.0.1
neural-compressor 2.1.1
(rest of them are all up to date)

title: Installation of version1.0b0 via pip fails
body:
Installation of the default version1.0b0 with pip fails with the following error:

```
      Traceback (most recent call last):
        File "<string>", line 2, in <module>
        File "<pip-setuptools-caller>", line 34, in <module>
        File "/tmp/pip-install-836hiul0/intel-extension-for-transformers_bf12f96abdef43088691034a0720ecc9/setup.py", line 185, in <module>
          check_submodules()
        File "/tmp/pip-install-836hiul0/intel-extension-for-transformers_bf12f96abdef43088691034a0720ecc9/setup.py", line 162, in check_submodules
          with open(git_modules_path) as f:
      FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/tmp/pip-install-836hiul0/intel-extension-for-transformers_bf12f96abdef43088691034a0720ecc9/.gitmodules'

```

However, installing the previous release works:

pip install intel-extension-for-transformers==1.0a0

title: Please add in requirements file version of neural-compressor <= 1.14.2
body:
It seems like ITREX is not compatible with INC 2.0 API. It would be helpful to add <= 1.14.2 constraint on neural-compressor.

Also, in your demo of BERT-mini, there is an import line that doesn't pass here: https://github.com/intel/intel-extension-for-transformers/blob/main/examples/deployment/neural_engine/sparse/bert_mini/run_glue.py#L29

When changing it with the following it starts working:

"""from intel_extension_for_transformers.optimization.model import OptimizedModel
    from intel_extension_for_transformers.optimization.config import QuantizationConfig
    from intel_extension_for_transformers.optimization.utils import metrics, objectives"""

Thanks :)
